results.headline: Three Boys Entangled in Mass Hysteria
results.summary_short: “Devil’s Knot” stays within the facts in chronicling the wrongful convictions of three teenagers in the brutal killings of three 8-year-old boys in the Arkansas woods.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Devil's Knot

results.headline: A Plea to Let Those Waters Flow
results.summary_short: The documentary “DamNation” argues against human interference with rivers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of DamNation

results.headline: Man in the Kitchen Is Hungry for Love
results.summary_short: In “Chef,” the director and writer Jon Favreau plays a high-end Los Angeles chef whose rise to gastronomic stardom is abruptly ended by a restaurant critic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chef

results.headline: The Theater of Tough Beginnings
results.summary_short: Part documentary and part fictional entertainment, “Still I Strive” takes viewers inside a Cambodian orphanage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still I Strive

results.headline: Just Try Borrowing a Cup of Sugar
results.summary_short: In “Neighbors,” a young married couple start to feel old living next to a house full of hard-partying fraternity brothers, and turf war breaks out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neighbors

results.headline: An Artist Who Let His Ideas (and Others) Do the Work
results.summary_short: Chris Teerink’s eye-catching and informative new documentary about the American conceptual artist Sol LeWitt is much more about his work than the man himself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sol LeWitt

results.headline: A Portrait of the Outsider Artist, Older and Still Unfiltered
results.summary_short: Llyn Foulkes, now 79, comes across in this film as a mostly lovable, cranky and brilliant outsider with a chip on his shoulder about not getting his due.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Llyn Foulkes One Man Band

results.headline: Tiny Mouths to Feed, a Path Often Fraught
results.summary_short: “Breastmilk,” an agenda-free documentary by Dana Ben-Ari, observes the nursing journeys of five new mothers in New York City.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breastmilk

results.headline: Done In by Décolletage and Defeatism
results.summary_short: In “Walk of Shame,” Elizabeth Banks plays a TV newswoman who applies for a job in New York, assumes she did not get it and goes out on a night on the town that leads to a run of bad luck.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walk of Shame

results.headline: An Innocent Awakened
results.summary_short: In “Ida,” set in Poland in 1962, an orphaned young novice in a convent finds her life turned upside down when a cynical, previously unknown aunt turns up.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ida

results.display_title: Speak the Music: Robert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music
results.headline: A Life in a String Quartet, and Beyond
results.summary_short: Robert Mann, a violinist and founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet, had to maintain a student’s outlook in his half-century with the group.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speak the Music: Robert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music

results.display_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage
results.headline: Kevin Spacey and Company Hit the Road
results.summary_short: “NOW” follows Kevin Spacey and his fellow actors in a production of “Richard III” that is staged around the world, from Beijing to Brooklyn.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage

results.headline: A Man and His Elephant, and Flying Fists
results.summary_short: A sequel to “The Protector” revolves around another kidnapping of the sacred elephant Khon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Protector 2

results.headline: A Life Story of Glitter and Tragedy
results.summary_short: “Jobriath A.D.” is a documentary about a 1970s glam-rocker who came to a sad end.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jobriath A.D.

results.headline: Curse of the Abominable Snow Mutants
results.summary_short: In “Blood Glacier,” people at an Alpine weather station face an onslaught of mutant creatures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Glacier

results.headline: Insert an Emoticon Here
results.summary_short: The comedy “Friended to Death” uses a noxious protagonist to look at social media.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friended to Death

results.headline: Looking for a Welcome in the American Melting Pot
results.summary_short: Jose Antonio Vargas, director of “Documented,” uses his own story to campaign for the rights of immigrants.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Documented

results.headline: Revisiting Familial Territory
results.summary_short: The French director Diane Kurys has a penchant for working and reworking the story of her parents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pour une femme

results.headline: On the Trail of a Gene That Kills
results.summary_short: “Decoding Annie Parker” follows two roads to the discovery of a genetic link to breast cancer: A Canadian woman with numerous dead relatives and the same disease that killed them, and a scientist doggedly working on a far-fetched theory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Decoding Annie Parker

results.headline: The Future Is So Dark, Pack a Lamp
results.summary_short: “Beneath the Harvest Sky” tells the story of two teenagers in a Maine town on the Canadian border, facing limited choices and desperate to find a way out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beneath The Harvest Sky
